question.title: How To: Java memory manpulation with JNA on Windows

node.contents: The question should be reopened because OP's motivation was to provide his own (very detailed) answer. However, the text of the question itself *is* quite poor.

node.contents: I'm not really sure how to improve the question. But if someone knows, let me know.

node.contents: `a lot of people want to manipulate memory on Windows OS with Java.` I doubt this very much, but you can do this with Unsafe or https://github.com/OpenHFT/Java-Lang version 6.0

astNode.text: `a lot of people want to manipulate memory on Windows OS with Java.` I doubt this very much, but you can do this with Unsafe or https://github.com/OpenHFT/Java-Lang version 6.0

node.contents: The intent definetly matches the [FAQ](http://stackoverflow.com/help/self-answer) and the question itself was improved. I think it should be reopened

astNode.text: The intent definetly matches the [FAQ](http://stackoverflow.com/help/self-answer) and the question itself was improved. I think it should be reopened

node.contents: How do I manipulate memory with Java?

astNode.text: How do I manipulate memory with Java?

node.contents: Java runs in it's own JVM, so how could I access the memory?

astNode.text: Java runs in it's own JVM, so how could I access the memory?

node.contents: I heard about JNA. How can I use it to get interfaces between the Operating System and my Java code?

astNode.text: I heard about JNA. How can I use it to get interfaces between the Operating System and my Java code?

node.contents: Let's say, I want to manipulate the score of Solitaire. How would I do this?

astNode.text: Let's say, I want to manipulate the score of Solitaire. How would I do this?

node.contents: The attempt would be something like this

astNode.text: The attempt would be something like this

node.contents:
• get the process of solitaire
  • get access to the memory of solitaire
  • find out where the score is stored in the memory
  • write my new value in the address

astNode.text:
• get the process of solitaire
  • get access to the memory of solitaire
  • find out where the score is stored in the memory
  • write my new value in the address

node.contents: But Java itself can't access to the memory, so how would JNA help me to do this?

astNode.text: But Java itself can't access to the memory, so how would JNA help me to do this?

node.contents: You need to use the JNA Library. Download the two Jar-Files (jna.jar and jna-platform.jar)

astNode.text: You need to use the JNA Library. Download the two Jar-Files (jna.jar and jna-platform.jar)

node.contents: I found a tutorial on pastebin, which explains how to use this Library. But it won't be necessary to read it to understand the following.

astNode.text: I found a tutorial on pastebin, which explains how to use this Library. But it won't be necessary to read it to understand the following.

node.contents: Let's say, you want to manipulate the addresses and their values of the Windows game "Solitaire"

astNode.text: Let's say, you want to manipulate the addresses and their values of the Windows game "Solitaire"

node.contents: <hr />

astNode.text: <hr />

node.contents: Know, what you do

astNode.text: Know, what you do

node.contents:
1. If you want to manipulate addresses and their values, know what you do!
    You need to know, what size the value, stored in the address, has. Is it 4Byte, or 8Byte or whatsoever.

  2. Know how to use tools to get dynamic and base-addresses. I use CheatEngine.

  3. Know the difference bewteen base-addresses, and dynamic-addresses:

    • Dynamic-addresses will change every time you restart the application (Solitaire).
      They will contain the needed value, but you would need to find the address again every time. So what you need to learn first, is how to get the base-address.
      Learn this by playing through the CheatEngine Tutorial.

    • Base-addresses are static addresses. Those addresses point to other addresses mostly the following way: [[base-addres + offset] + offset] -> value. So what you need is to know the base-address, and the offsets you need to add to the addresses to get the dynamic-address.

astNode.text:
1. If you want to manipulate addresses and their values, know what you do!
    You need to know, what size the value, stored in the address, has. Is it 4Byte, or 8Byte or whatsoever.

  2. Know how to use tools to get dynamic and base-addresses. I use CheatEngine.

  3. Know the difference bewteen base-addresses, and dynamic-addresses:

    • Dynamic-addresses will change every time you restart the application (Solitaire).
      They will contain the needed value, but you would need to find the address again every time. So what you need to learn first, is how to get the base-address.
      Learn this by playing through the CheatEngine Tutorial.

    • Base-addresses are static addresses. Those addresses point to other addresses mostly the following way: [[base-addres + offset] + offset] -> value. So what you need is to know the base-address, and the offsets you need to add to the addresses to get the dynamic-address.

node.contents: So now that you know what you need to know you do some research with the CheatEngine on Solitaire.

astNode.text: So now that you know what you need to know you do some research with the CheatEngine on Solitaire.

node.contents: <hr />

astNode.text: <hr />

node.contents: You found your dynamic-address and searched for the base-address? Good, let's share our results:

astNode.text: You found your dynamic-address and searched for the base-address? Good, let's share our results:

node.contents:
Base-address for the score: 0x10002AFA8
Offsets to get to the dynamic-address: 0x50 (first) and 0x14 (second)

astNode.text:
Base-address for the score: 0x10002AFA8
Offsets to get to the dynamic-address: 0x50 (first) and 0x14 (second)

node.contents: Got everything right? Good! Let's continue with actually writing some code.

astNode.text: Got everything right? Good! Let's continue with actually writing some code.

node.contents: <hr />

astNode.text: <hr />

node.contents: Create a new Project

astNode.text: Create a new Project

node.contents: In your new project, you need to import those libraries. I use Eclipse, but it should work on any other IDE.

astNode.text: In your new project, you need to import those libraries. I use Eclipse, but it should work on any other IDE.

node.contents: User32 Interface

astNode.text: User32 Interface

node.contents: Thank's to Todd Fast, for setting up an User32 interface. It's not complete, but enough we need here.

astNode.text: Thank's to Todd Fast, for setting up an User32 interface. It's not complete, but enough we need here.

node.contents: With this interface, we get access to some functions of the user32.dll on Windows. We need the following functions: FindWindowA and GetWindowThreadProcessID

astNode.text: With this interface, we get access to some functions of the user32.dll on Windows. We need the following functions: FindWindowA and GetWindowThreadProcessID

node.contents: Side Note: If Eclipse tells you it needs to add unimplemented methods, just ignore it and run the code anyway.

astNode.text: Side Note: If Eclipse tells you it needs to add unimplemented methods, just ignore it and run the code anyway.

node.contents: Kernel32 Interface

astNode.text: Kernel32 Interface

node.contents: Thank's to Deject3d for the Kernel32 interface. I modified it a little bit.

astNode.text: Thank's to Deject3d for the Kernel32 interface. I modified it a little bit.

node.contents: This interface contains the methods we use to read and write to memory. WriteProcessMemory and ReadProcessMemory. It also contains a method to open a process OpenProcess

astNode.text: This interface contains the methods we use to read and write to memory. WriteProcessMemory and ReadProcessMemory. It also contains a method to open a process OpenProcess

node.contents: Actual Manipulation

astNode.text: Actual Manipulation

node.contents: We now create a new class which will contain some helper methods and the main function as access point for the JVM.

astNode.text: We now create a new class which will contain some helper methods and the main function as access point for the JVM.

elements.contents: public class SolitaireHack { public static void main(String... args) { } }

units.rawText: public class SolitaireHack { public static void main(String... args) { } }

node.contents: Let's fill in stuff we already know, like our offsets and the base-address.

astNode.text: Let's fill in stuff we already know, like our offsets and the base-address.

elements.contents: public class SolitaireHack { final static long baseAddress = 0x10002AFA8L; final static int[] offsets = new int[]{0x50,0x14}; public static void main(String... args) { } }

units.rawText: public class SolitaireHack { final static long baseAddress = 0x10002AFA8L; final static int[] offsets = new int[]{0x50,0x14}; public static void main(String... args) { } }

node.contents: Next we use our interfaces to get access to our Windows specific methods:

astNode.text: Next we use our interfaces to get access to our Windows specific methods:

node.contents: import com.sun.jna.Native;

astNode.text: import com.sun.jna.Native;

elements.contents: public class SolitaireHack { final static long baseAddress = 0x10002AFA8L; final static int[] offsets = new int[]{0x50,0x14}; static Kernel32 kernel32 = (Kernel32) Native.loadLibrary("kernel32",Kernel32.class); static User32 user32 = (User32) Native.loadLibrary("user32", User32.class); public static void main(String... args) { } }

units.rawText: public class SolitaireHack { final static long baseAddress = 0x10002AFA8L; final static int[] offsets = new int[]{0x50,0x14}; static Kernel32 kernel32 = (Kernel32) Native.loadLibrary("kernel32",Kernel32.class); static User32 user32 = (User32) Native.loadLibrary("user32", User32.class); public static void main(String... args) { } }

node.contents: Last but not least we create some permission constants we need, to get the permission to read and write to a process.

astNode.text: Last but not least we create some permission constants we need, to get the permission to read and write to a process.

elements.contents: import com.sun.jna.Native; public class SolitaireHack { final static long baseAddress = 0x10002AFA8L; final static int[] offsets = new int[]{0x50,0x14}; static Kernel32 kernel32 = (Kernel32) Native.loadLibrary("kernel32",Kernel32.class); static User32 user32 = (User32) Native.loadLibrary("user32", User32.class); public static int PROCESS_VM_READ= 0x0010; public static int PROCESS_VM_WRITE = 0x0020; public static int PROCESS_VM_OPERATION = 0x0008; public static void main(String... args) { } }

units.rawText: import com.sun.jna.Native; public class SolitaireHack { final static long baseAddress = 0x10002AFA8L; final static int[] offsets = new int[]{0x50,0x14}; static Kernel32 kernel32 = (Kernel32) Native.loadLibrary("kernel32",Kernel32.class); static User32 user32 = (User32) Native.loadLibrary("user32", User32.class); public static int PROCESS_VM_READ= 0x0010; public static int PROCESS_VM_WRITE = 0x0020; public static int PROCESS_VM_OPERATION = 0x0008; public static void main(String... args) { } }

node.contents: In order to get a process, where we can manipulate the memory, we need to get the window. This window can be used to get the process id. With this id we can open the process.

astNode.text: In order to get a process, where we can manipulate the memory, we need to get the window. This window can be used to get the process id. With this id we can open the process.

elements.contents: public static void main(String... args) { int pid = getProcessId("Solitaire"); Pointer process = openProcess(PROCESS_VM_READ|PROCESS_VM_WRITE|PROCESS_VM_OPERATION, pid); } public static int getProcessId(String window) { IntByReference pid = new IntByReference(0); user32.GetWindowThreadProcessId(user32.FindWindowA(null, window), pid); return pid.getValue(); } public static Pointer openProcess(int permissions, int pid) { Pointer process = kernel32.OpenProcess(permissions, true, pid); return process; }

units.rawText: public static void main(String... args) { int pid = getProcessId("Solitaire"); Pointer process = openProcess(PROCESS_VM_READ|PROCESS_VM_WRITE|PROCESS_VM_OPERATION, pid); } public static int getProcessId(String window) { IntByReference pid = new IntByReference(0); user32.GetWindowThreadProcessId(user32.FindWindowA(null, window), pid); return pid.getValue(); } public static Pointer openProcess(int permissions, int pid) { Pointer process = kernel32.OpenProcess(permissions, true, pid); return process; }

node.contents: In the getProcessId method we use the parameter, which is the title of the window, to find the window handle. (FindWindowA) This window handle is used to get the process id. An IntByReference is the JNA version of an pointer, where the process id will be stored.

astNode.text: In the getProcessId method we use the parameter, which is the title of the window, to find the window handle. (FindWindowA) This window handle is used to get the process id. An IntByReference is the JNA version of an pointer, where the process id will be stored.

node.contents: If you get the process id, you can use it to open the process with openProcess. This method gets the permissions and the pid, to open the process, and returns a pointer to it. To read from a process you need the permission PROCESS_VM_READ and to write from a process you need the permissions PROCESS_VM_WRITE and PROCESS_VM_OPERATION.

astNode.text: If you get the process id, you can use it to open the process with openProcess. This method gets the permissions and the pid, to open the process, and returns a pointer to it. To read from a process you need the permission PROCESS_VM_READ and to write from a process you need the permissions PROCESS_VM_WRITE and PROCESS_VM_OPERATION.

node.contents: The next thing we need to get is the actual address. The dynamic-address. So we need another method:

astNode.text: The next thing we need to get is the actual address. The dynamic-address. So we need another method:

elements.contents: public static void main(String... args) { int pid = getProcessId("Solitaire"); Pointer process = openProcess(PROCESS_VM_READ|PROCESS_VM_WRITE|PROCESS_VM_OPERATION, pid); long dynAddress = findDynAddress(process,offsets,baseAddress); } public static long findDynAddress(Pointer process, int[] offsets, long baseAddress) { long pointer = baseAddress; int size = 4; Memory pTemp = new Memory(size); long pointerAddress = 0; for(int i = 0; i < offsets.length; i++) { if(i == 0) { kernel32.ReadProcessMemory(process, pointer, pTemp, size, null); } pointerAddress = ((pTemp.getInt(0)+offsets[i])); if(i != offsets.length-1) kernel32.ReadProcessMemory(process, pointerAddress, pTemp, size, null); } return pointerAddress; }

units.rawText: public static void main(String... args) { int pid = getProcessId("Solitaire"); Pointer process = openProcess(PROCESS_VM_READ|PROCESS_VM_WRITE|PROCESS_VM_OPERATION, pid); long dynAddress = findDynAddress(process,offsets,baseAddress); } public static long findDynAddress(Pointer process, int[] offsets, long baseAddress) { long pointer = baseAddress; int size = 4; Memory pTemp = new Memory(size); long pointerAddress = 0; for(int i = 0; i < offsets.length; i++) { if(i == 0) { kernel32.ReadProcessMemory(process, pointer, pTemp, size, null); } pointerAddress = ((pTemp.getInt(0)+offsets[i])); if(i != offsets.length-1) kernel32.ReadProcessMemory(process, pointerAddress, pTemp, size, null); } return pointerAddress; }

node.contents: This method needs the process, the offsets and the base-address. It stores some temporary data in a Memory object, which is exactly what it says. A memory. It reads out at the base-address, gets back a new address in the memory and adds the offset. This is done for all offsets and returns in the end the last address, which will be the dynamic-address.

astNode.text: This method needs the process, the offsets and the base-address. It stores some temporary data in a Memory object, which is exactly what it says. A memory. It reads out at the base-address, gets back a new address in the memory and adds the offset. This is done for all offsets and returns in the end the last address, which will be the dynamic-address.

node.contents: So now we want to read our score and print it out. We have the dynamic-addres where the score is stored and just need to read it out. The score is a 4Byte value. Integer is a 4Byte datatype. So we can use an Integer to read it out.

astNode.text: So now we want to read our score and print it out. We have the dynamic-addres where the score is stored and just need to read it out. The score is a 4Byte value. Integer is a 4Byte datatype. So we can use an Integer to read it out.

elements.contents: public static void main(String... args) { int pid = getProcessId("Solitaire"); Pointer process = openProcess(PROCESS_VM_READ|PROCESS_VM_WRITE|PROCESS_VM_OPERATION, pid); long dynAddress = findDynAddress(process,offsets,baseAddress); Memory scoreMem = readMemory(process,dynAddress,4); int score = scoreMem.getInt(0); System.out.println(score); } public static Memory readMemory(Pointer process, long address, int bytesToRead) { IntByReference read = new IntByReference(0); Memory output = new Memory(bytesToRead); kernel32.ReadProcessMemory(process, address, output, bytesToRead, read); return output; }

units.rawText: public static void main(String... args) { int pid = getProcessId("Solitaire"); Pointer process = openProcess(PROCESS_VM_READ|PROCESS_VM_WRITE|PROCESS_VM_OPERATION, pid); long dynAddress = findDynAddress(process,offsets,baseAddress); Memory scoreMem = readMemory(process,dynAddress,4); int score = scoreMem.getInt(0); System.out.println(score); } public static Memory readMemory(Pointer process, long address, int bytesToRead) { IntByReference read = new IntByReference(0); Memory output = new Memory(bytesToRead); kernel32.ReadProcessMemory(process, address, output, bytesToRead, read); return output; }

node.contents: We wrote a wrapper for our kernel32 method readProcessMemory. We know we need to read 4Byte so the bytesToRead will be 4. In the method, a Memory object will be created and returned, which will have the size of byteToRead and store the data, contained in our address. With the .getInt(0) method we can read out the Integer value of our memory at the offset 0.

astNode.text: We wrote a wrapper for our kernel32 method readProcessMemory. We know we need to read 4Byte so the bytesToRead will be 4. In the method, a Memory object will be created and returned, which will have the size of byteToRead and store the data, contained in our address. With the .getInt(0) method we can read out the Integer value of our memory at the offset 0.

node.contents: Play a little bit with your solitaire, and get some points. Then run your code and read out the value. Check if it's your score.

astNode.text: Play a little bit with your solitaire, and get some points. Then run your code and read out the value. Check if it's your score.

node.contents: Our last step will be to manipulate our score. We want to be the best. So we need to write 4Byte data to our memory.

astNode.text: Our last step will be to manipulate our score. We want to be the best. So we need to write 4Byte data to our memory.

node.contents:
This will be our new score. newScore[0] will be the lowest byte and newScore[3] will be the highest one. So if you wanted to change your score to the value 20 your byte[] would be:
byte[] newScore = new byte[]{0x14,0x00,0x00,0x00};

astNode.text:
This will be our new score. newScore[0] will be the lowest byte and newScore[3] will be the highest one. So if you wanted to change your score to the value 20 your byte[] would be:
byte[] newScore = new byte[]{0x14,0x00,0x00,0x00};

node.contents: Let's write it in our memory:

astNode.text: Let's write it in our memory:

elements.contents: public static void main(String... args) { int pid = getProcessId("Solitaire"); Pointer process = openProcess(PROCESS_VM_READ|PROCESS_VM_WRITE|PROCESS_VM_OPERATION, pid); long dynAddress = findDynAddress(process,offsets,baseAddress); Memory scoreMem = readMemory(process,dynAddress,4); int score = scoreMem.getInt(0); System.out.println(score); byte[] newScore = new byte[]{0x22,0x22,0x22,0x22}; writeMemory(process, dynAddress, newScore); } public static void writeMemory(Pointer process, long address, byte[] data) { int size = data.length; Memory toWrite = new Memory(size); for(int i = 0; i < size; i++) { toWrite.setByte(i, data[i]); } boolean b = kernel32.WriteProcessMemory(process, address, toWrite, size, null); }

units.rawText: public static void main(String... args) { int pid = getProcessId("Solitaire"); Pointer process = openProcess(PROCESS_VM_READ|PROCESS_VM_WRITE|PROCESS_VM_OPERATION, pid); long dynAddress = findDynAddress(process,offsets,baseAddress); Memory scoreMem = readMemory(process,dynAddress,4); int score = scoreMem.getInt(0); System.out.println(score); byte[] newScore = new byte[]{0x22,0x22,0x22,0x22}; writeMemory(process, dynAddress, newScore); } public static void writeMemory(Pointer process, long address, byte[] data) { int size = data.length; Memory toWrite = new Memory(size); for(int i = 0; i < size; i++) { toWrite.setByte(i, data[i]); } boolean b = kernel32.WriteProcessMemory(process, address, toWrite, size, null); }

node.contents: With our writeMemory method, we write a byte[] called data to our address. We create a new Memory object and set the size to the length of the array. We write the data to the Memory object with the correct offsets and write the object to our address.

astNode.text: With our writeMemory method, we write a byte[] called data to our address. We create a new Memory object and set the size to the length of the array. We write the data to the Memory object with the correct offsets and write the object to our address.

node.contents: Now you should have the fantastic score of 572662306.

astNode.text: Now you should have the fantastic score of 572662306.

node.contents: If you don't get the process id of Solitaire, just check it in your Task Manager and write in the pid manually. The german Solitär won't work, i think because of the ä in the name.

node.contents: I hope you liked this tutorial. Most parts are from some other tutorials, but put all together here, so in case someone needs a starting point, this should help.

node.contents: Let's have a look at the full code of the SolitaireHack Class:

astNode.text: Let's have a look at the full code of the SolitaireHack Class:

elements.contents: import com.sun.jna.Memory; import com.sun.jna.Native; import com.sun.jna.Pointer; import com.sun.jna.ptr.IntByReference; public class SolitaireHack { final static long baseAddress = 0x10002AFA8L; final static int[] offsets = new int[]{0x50,0x14}; static Kernel32 kernel32 = (Kernel32) Native.loadLibrary("kernel32",Kernel32.class); static User32 user32 = (User32) Native.loadLibrary("user32", User32.class); public static int PROCESS_VM_READ= 0x0010; public static int PROCESS_VM_WRITE = 0x0020; public static int PROCESS_VM_OPERATION = 0x0008; public static void main(String... args) { int pid = getProcessId("Solitaire"); Pointer process = openProcess(PROCESS_VM_READ|PROCESS_VM_WRITE|PROCESS_VM_OPERATION, pid); long dynAddress = findDynAddress(process,offsets,baseAddress); Memory scoreMem = readMemory(process,dynAddress,4); int score = scoreMem.getInt(0); System.out.println(score); byte[] newScore = new byte[]{0x22,0x22,0x22,0x22}; writeMemory(process, dynAddress, newScore); } public static int getProcessId(String window) { IntByReference pid = new IntByReference(0); user32.GetWindowThreadProcessId(user32.FindWindowA(null, window), pid); return pid.getValue(); } public static Pointer openProcess(int permissions, int pid) { Pointer process = kernel32.OpenProcess(permissions, true, pid); return process; } public static long findDynAddress(Pointer process, int[] offsets, long baseAddress) { long pointer = baseAddress; int size = 4; Memory pTemp = new Memory(size); long pointerAddress = 0; for(int i = 0; i < offsets.length; i++) { if(i == 0) { kernel32.ReadProcessMemory(process, pointer, pTemp, size, null); } pointerAddress = ((pTemp.getInt(0)+offsets[i])); if(i != offsets.length-1) kernel32.ReadProcessMemory(process, pointerAddress, pTemp, size, null); } return pointerAddress; } public static Memory readMemory(Pointer process, long address, int bytesToRead) { IntByReference read = new IntByReference(0); Memory output = new Memory(bytesToRead); kernel32.ReadProcessMemory(process, address, output, bytesToRead, read); return output; } public static void writeMemory(Pointer process, long address, byte[] data) { int size = data.length; Memory toWrite = new Memory(size); for(int i = 0; i < size; i++) { toWrite.setByte(i, data[i]); } boolean b = kernel32.WriteProcessMemory(process, address, toWrite, size, null); } }

units.rawText: import com.sun.jna.Memory; import com.sun.jna.Native; import com.sun.jna.Pointer; import com.sun.jna.ptr.IntByReference; public class SolitaireHack { final static long baseAddress = 0x10002AFA8L; final static int[] offsets = new int[]{0x50,0x14}; static Kernel32 kernel32 = (Kernel32) Native.loadLibrary("kernel32",Kernel32.class); static User32 user32 = (User32) Native.loadLibrary("user32", User32.class); public static int PROCESS_VM_READ= 0x0010; public static int PROCESS_VM_WRITE = 0x0020; public static int PROCESS_VM_OPERATION = 0x0008; public static void main(String... args) { int pid = getProcessId("Solitaire"); Pointer process = openProcess(PROCESS_VM_READ|PROCESS_VM_WRITE|PROCESS_VM_OPERATION, pid); long dynAddress = findDynAddress(process,offsets,baseAddress); Memory scoreMem = readMemory(process,dynAddress,4); int score = scoreMem.getInt(0); System.out.println(score); byte[] newScore = new byte[]{0x22,0x22,0x22,0x22}; writeMemory(process, dynAddress, newScore); } public static int getProcessId(String window) { IntByReference pid = new IntByReference(0); user32.GetWindowThreadProcessId(user32.FindWindowA(null, window), pid); return pid.getValue(); } public static Pointer openProcess(int permissions, int pid) { Pointer process = kernel32.OpenProcess(permissions, true, pid); return process; } public static long findDynAddress(Pointer process, int[] offsets, long baseAddress) { long pointer = baseAddress; int size = 4; Memory pTemp = new Memory(size); long pointerAddress = 0; for(int i = 0; i < offsets.length; i++) { if(i == 0) { kernel32.ReadProcessMemory(process, pointer, pTemp, size, null); } pointerAddress = ((pTemp.getInt(0)+offsets[i])); if(i != offsets.length-1) kernel32.ReadProcessMemory(process, pointerAddress, pTemp, size, null); } return pointerAddress; } public static Memory readMemory(Pointer process, long address, int bytesToRead) { IntByReference read = new IntByReference(0); Memory output = new Memory(bytesToRead); kernel32.ReadProcessMemory(process, address, output, bytesToRead, read); return output; } public static void writeMemory(Pointer process, long address, byte[] data) { int size = data.length; Memory toWrite = new Memory(size); for(int i = 0; i < size; i++) { toWrite.setByte(i, data[i]); } boolean b = kernel32.WriteProcessMemory(process, address, toWrite, size, null); } }

node.contents: @Loki What possible motivation could a real user have to insist on using JNA? This answer improves on what is asked for, if anything.

astNode.text: @Loki What possible motivation could a real user have to insist on using JNA? This answer improves on what is asked for, if anything.

node.contents: At what point is this JNA? Does your library use JNA?

astNode.text: At what point is this JNA? Does your library use JNA?

node.contents: @Loki Sorry, it doesn't use JNA at all and no extra JNI libraries, just JVM builtins. It uses Unsafe intrinsics as much as possible (which get turned into a single machine code instruction instead of JNI)

astNode.text: @Loki Sorry, it doesn't use JNA at all and no extra JNI libraries, just JVM builtins. It uses Unsafe intrinsics as much as possible (which get turned into a single machine code instruction instead of JNI)

node.contents: Using https://github.com/OpenHFT/Java-Lang you can do

elements.contents: long size = 1L << 40; // 1 TB DirectStore store = DirectStore.allocate(size); DirectBytes slice = store.createSlice(); slice.writeLong(0, size); slice.writeLong(size - 8, size); store.free();

node.contents: The DirectByte can point arbitrary addresses in memory or be allocated with malloc

astNode.text: The DirectByte can point arbitrary addresses in memory or be allocated with malloc
